title: Dulux owner Akzo Nobel says China property boom is over

Tue, Jul 21, 2015, 13:51 BST - UK Markets close in 2 hrs 39 mins Dulux owner Akzo Nobel says China property boom is over By Alan Tovey | Telegraph – 41 minutes ago 70.29 +0.87 
Paint-maker and specialty chemicals company Akzo Nobel (Amsterdam: AKZA.AS - news ) reports rise in revenues and profits but signals weakness in major markets 
China’s property boom of the past decade is well and truly over, according to the chief executive of paint-maker Akzo Nobel . 
Ton Büchner, chief executive of the company which owns the Dulux paint brand, said the company was having to work out how to deal with a changing global economy as he reported second-quarter results. 
“China’s growth trajectory has slowed down significantly,” he said. “China is not the constantly growing construction market that it has been for the past 10 years and we need to adjust to that.” 
Netherlands-based paint and chemicals company Akzo which took over the Dulux brand when it bought ICI for £8bn in 2008 said that group revenues rose by 6pc to €3.9bn (£2.7bn) in the three months to June. 
The company's sales growth is often seen as a bellwether for economic prosperity in the countries in which it operates. Demand for its paints reflects how often people are moving house and splashing out on redecorating, while sales of industrial paint and chemical supplies gives an insight into the underlying health of a nation's industry and commercial companies. 
Mr Büchner said that Europe had proved to be a “very, very tough” market over the past few years, though there were pockets of strength. 
“The UK was the first to recover, followed by the Netherlands this year,” he said. “There is weakness in France, and Spain is recovering but from a very, very low base... this is the run-up to the season for buying decorative paint.” 
Looking farther afield, he said Eastern Europe was seeing a lot of volatility because of Russia, while Latin America was suffering amid the downturn in demand for natural resources. North America is improving and while China is difficult, new markets in Asia, such as Indonesia and Vietnam, are improving. 
Akzo Nobel says it is being hit by a downturn in demand in Latin America 
Decorative paint, Akzo’s smallest division, had sales of €1.1bn in the quarter, a rise of 6pc. Specialty chemicals, which are used in detergents, foods, cosmetics and construction, saw sales increase 5pc to €1.3bn while performance coatings, which makes paints used in industries such as aerospace, shipbuillding and the oil and gas, posted an 8pc jump in revenues to €1.5bn. 
“The oil and gas sectors are cutting back on paint for their oil platforms and refineries, they are clearly hurting,” said Mr Büchner, adding that Akzo was also seeing the backlog from shipyards falling, with less demand to repaint ships. 
Akzo Nobel's performance coatings unit makes paint used to protect ships 
“In the consumer area, if people are buying furniture it is generally painted, and most consumer goods such as mobile phones have a coating of some kind. We are seeing steady growth in the area,” he added. 
Currency movements were largely behind the increase in revenue, with Akzo’s international sales delivering a top line boost as the company reports in the euro, which has weakened recently. Akzo said foreign exchange movements lifted results by 9pc but this was pared back by lower volumes and the sale of businesses. 
Cost controls helped to drive operating profits 38pc higher tp €486m, and the return on sales grew to 12.3pc, up from 9.5pc a year ago. 
“We get a benefit from currency movements [on revenue] but not really on return on sales,” said Mr Büchner, who added the company is on track to hit its full-year targets. “Currency does have some benefit on raw material costs.”
